AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
At the Movies: `Valmont,' `Enemies, a Love Story'

Eds: ``Valmont'' opened in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles and Toronto Nov. 17 and is being released elsewhere through January. ``Enemies'' opened in New York on Nov. 13 and will be released elsewhere in coming months.
DOC.TEXT:
``Valmont''
Filmmakers seem to have a love affair with Choderlos de Laclos' 1782 epistolary novel, ``Les Liaisons Dangereuses.'' And with his story of seduction, hedonism and revenge in 18th century France, it's no surprise. The work was first interpreted on film by Roger Vadim in 1959. It starred Gerard Phillipe and Jeanne Moreau as Vicomte de Valmont and his wife, Juliette, two icy, modern-day opportunists with an ``open marriage.'' It had a jazzy score by Thelonius Monk and Jack Murray. The second movie version was last year's ``Dangerous Liaisons,'' an Americanized, fast-paced drama directed by Stephen Frears and starring Glenn Close as the scheming Marquise de Merteuil and John Malkovich as the notorious rake Valmont. Now comes Milos Forman with ``Valmont,'' and it is as different from the other efforts as the many interpretations of William Shakespeare's ``Hamlet.'' It is a lush and elegant movie, graced by the seductive camera work of Miroslav Ondricek. With a keen eye for detail _ cheese wrapped in leaves in the market, a bathtub with a little bench on which to sit, Forman eases into de Laclos' story against the blind morals of prerevolutionary France. His vision is sweeping _ there's no rush but still much activity. Forman loves the bustle and business of earlier times _ jugglers, merchants, servants always underfoot. As Madame de Merteuil, Annette Bening brings a sugary bitchiness. She is less brittle than the Glenn Close interpretation and also less focused. But her intent is clear: She loves playing games, wicked, vicious games that ultimately destroy people and bring ruin to a way of life. Colin Firth's Valmont is far more attractive than Malkovich's. Indeed, one wondered why women would ever be drawn to the Malkovich character, with his pasty visage and deep-set eyes, and Bronx sounding voice. Firth is almost too cute, almost too soft. He's sexy, sensual, flirty. But the steely maliciousness is missing. Meg Tilly, who is about to emerge as a leading actress with her role in ``Valmont'' and her upcoming part as Harvey Keitel's unfaithful wife in ``The Two Jakes,'' is convincing as the vulnerable and pious young wife Madame de Tourvel. She is the woman Valmont worships and for whom he lusts. Fairuza Balk, who starred in the horrendous ``Return to Oz,'' portrays Cecile, the target of Valmont's seduction and the innocent victim of Merteuil's revenge. Her mother has arranged for the convent school girl to marry Gercourt, an older man who will take only a virgin as his wife. He's also Merteuil's ex-lover. Forman dances his characters about in a game of musical beds, a game that's a no-win for just about all. Jean-Claude Carriere's screenplay makes good use of de Laclos' focus on letter writing. Letters show up just about everywhere and even Valmont gets into the spirit by dictating erotic passages to an unsuspecting Cecile to send to the young music teacher (Henry Thomas) who loves her. Forman's denouement is almost anti-climatic. The duel and Valmont's death is almost a mirthful moment. But ``Valmont'' is worth watching. The Orion Pictures release has a running time of 134 minutes and is rated R.

``Enemies, a Love Story''
Herman Broder, who's never really been a faithful husband, leads what he thinks is a fairly uncomplicated and acceptable life: He has a wife in Brooklyn and a mistress in the Bronx. But when his first wife, whom he had thought was dead, suddenly shows up, his ``uncomplicated'' life becomes a shambles. Paul Mazursky has adapted a novel by Isaac Bashevis Singer and crafted it into a richly told human drama, ``Enemies, a Love Story.'' It's a tale filled with irony, humor, joy, tragedy set in the world of Holocaust survivors in New York, 1949. Herman (Ron Silver) survived the war by hiding in a hayloft. His family's former servant, Yadwiga (Margaret Sophie Stein), cared for him. What's a lad to do after the war? He marries her and brings her to America _ Coney Island, U.S.A. Yadwiga exists to be the perfect wife (slave). She polishes his bedroom slippers, practices Judaism so she can convert, never questions his many trips out of town to sell encyclopedias. The trips are to the Bronx home of his hot lover, Masha (Lena Olin). Theirs is a passionate and totally physical arrangement, despite the presence of Masha's mother. Herman can't live without Masha so he marries her. He feels obligated to Yadwiga and remains married to her as well. But Tamara (Anjelica Huston) is another story. Crippled by the Nazi bullets she took in her hip at a death camp, Tamara is the woman who bore his children, the woman who is all-woman and who knows him best. Her independence and humor about his current situation drive him up a wall. Still, he does not want to lose her. Mazursky's touch is masterful. He pulls just the right performances from his ensemble with little effort, and retains the integrity of each character. His camera is not judgmental. If anything, it acts as an understanding lover. Huston is marvelous: She's strong, witty, vulnerable but independent, sexy, knowing, charming and bitchy. Her accent is a little irritating at times, but soon is obscured by an excellent piece of acting. Olin, who so impressed with her role as one of the passionate lovers in ``The Unbearable Lightness of Being,'' gives a stunning and moving performance as the troubled Masha. Stein is a Polish stage and screen actress who makes her American movie debut with ``Enemies.'' She lends a tender grace to the simple adoring peasant woman, and emerges a strong film presence. Silver does most of his acting with expressions and moves. Herman is a man who harbors many ghosts and who, like many who survived the Nazis, is deeply scarred by history. It's what he doesn't say, what he doesn't do that tells us who he is. ``Enemies, a Love Story,'' is a deeply felt testament to any survivor at any time, and its universality is in its ability to caress the humanity and joy of everyday life. The Morgan Creek production for 20th Century Fox is rated R.
